clinical_study.brief_title: Dose-Finding Study of Favipiravir in the Treatment of Uncomplicated Influenza
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Multicenter Study Evaluating the Efficacy and Safety of Two Doses of Favipiravir in Adult Patients With Uncomplicated Influenza

brief_summary.textblock: This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled multicenter study evaluating the efficacy and safety of two doses of favipiravir in adult patients with uncomplicated influenza.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a 5-day regimen of favipiravir in influenza patients aged 20-80 years. Enrolled patients will be randomly assigned to 1 of 3 parallel treatment dose groups:Placebo; Low-dose favipiravir (1000 mg favipiravir BID for 1 day, followed by 400 mg favipiravir BID for 4 days); High-dose favipiravir (1200 mg favipiravir BID for 1 day, followed by 800 mg favipiravir BID for 4 days).

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Clinical Efficacy of 2 Dose Regimens of Favipiravir Compared With Placebo in Treating Patients With Influenza
primary_outcome.description: Overall time required from first study drug administration to alleviation of the 6 primary influenza symptoms and for temperature (oral) measurements to be less than 38.0°C for patients aged 20 to less than 65 years and less than 37.8°C for patients aged 65 years or older. "Alleviated" was defined as all 6 symptom scores had to be decreased to 1 or below and the decrease remain unchanged for 21.5 hours.

arm_group.description: Low-dose favipiravir regimen: 1000 mg favipiravir twice a day (BID) x 1 day, and 400 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days
High-dose favipiravir regimen: 1200 mg favipiravir BID x 1 day, and 800 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days

intervention.description: 1000 mg favipiravir BID x 1 day, and 400 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days
High-dose favipiravir regimen: 1200 mg favipiravir BID x 1 day, and 800 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days
Placebo BID x 1 day, and Placebo BID x 4 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients who test positive for influenza A or B by a commercially available Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) of the nasopharynx. A patient with a negative RAT result may still enroll if the sponsor and investigator agree that there is a known influenza outbreak circulating in the community.
2. Patients ≥ 20 but < 65 years of age with a temperature (oral) of 100.4°F (38.0°C) or more; patients ≥ 65 years of age with a temperature (oral) of 100.0°F (37.8°C) or more at the first visit, or in the 6 hours prior if antipyretics were taken.
3. Patients with 2 or more of the following symptoms (moderate to severe in intensity) at the time of enrollment:
- Cough
- Sore throat
- Headache
- Nasal congestion
- Feeling feverish
- Body aches and pains
- Fatigue (tiredness)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients who have had influenza symptoms or fever (i.e., one of the symptoms listed under the inclusion criteria) for 36 hours or more prior to study screening.
2. Patients who have underlying chronic respiratory disease (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], chronic bronchitis, diffuse panbronchiolitis, bronchiectasis, pulmonary emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, bronchial asthma, or old tuberculosis).
3. Patients who at the beginning of the study are suspected of having bacterial respiratory infection (i.e., expectoration of purulent or mucopurulent sputum and/or infiltrate in lung in a chest x-ray, etc.).
4. Patients who have serious chronic diseases. For example, patients with HIV, cancer (i.e., requiring chemotherapy within the preceding 6 months), cirrhosis (end-stage), and/or unstable renal, cardiac, pulmonary, neurologic, vascular, or endocrinologic disease states requiring medication dose adjustments within the last 30 days.

baseline.population: The Safety Population, defined as all patients who received study drug, was used for demographic and baseline characteristics and safety analyses, unless otherwise indicated.

class.title: Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander
More than one race, including Hispanic or Latino

measure.title: Rapid Antigen Test Result
measure.description: Tested positive for influenza A or B by a commercially available rapid antigen test of the nasopharynx. A patient with a negative rapid antigen test result was enrolled if the sponsor and investigator agreed that there was a known influenza outbreak circulating in the community.

outcome.title: Clinical Efficacy of 2 Dose Regimens of Favipiravir Compared With Placebo in Treating Patients With Influenza
outcome.description: Overall time required from first study drug administration to alleviation of the 6 primary influenza symptoms and for temperature (oral) measurements to be less than 38.0°C for patients aged 20 to less than 65 years and less than 37.8°C for patients aged 65 years or older. "Alleviated" was defined as all 6 symptom scores had to be decreased to 1 or below and the decrease remain unchanged for 21.5 hours.
outcome.population: The primary analysis population for efficacy analyses was the ITTI Population (N=333), defined as all patients who received at least 1 dose of study drug with any available efficacy data after randomization and who tested positive for influenza A or B by PCR assay or culture tests on Day 1 using determinations.

group.title: 1: Low Dose Favipiravir
group.description: Favipiravir: 1000 mg favipiravir BID x 1 day, and 400 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days

group.title: 2: High Dose Favipiravir
group.description: Favipiravir:1200 mg favipiravir BID x 1 day, and 800 mg favipiravir BID x 4 days

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo comparator: Placebo BID x 1 day, and Placebo BID x 4 days

measure.title: Clinical Efficacy of 2 Dose Regimens of Favipiravir Compared With Placebo in Treating Patients With Influenza
measure.description: Overall time required from first study drug administration to alleviation of the 6 primary influenza symptoms and for temperature (oral) measurements to be less than 38.0°C for patients aged 20 to less than 65 years and less than 37.8°C for patients aged 65 years or older. "Alleviated" was defined as all 6 symptom scores had to be decreased to 1 or below and the decrease remain unchanged for 21.5 hours.
measure.population: The primary analysis population for efficacy analyses was the ITTI Population (N=333), defined as all patients who received at least 1 dose of study drug with any available efficacy data after randomization and who tested positive for influenza A or B by PCR assay or culture tests on Day 1 using determinations.

analysis.groups_desc: Time required from first study drug administration to alleviation of the 6 primary influenza symptoms and fever. The primary influenza symptoms included cough, sore throat, headache, nasal congestion, body aches and pains, and fatigue. Symptoms were considered alleviated when all were decreased to ≤1 and decrease persisted unchanged ≥ 21.5 hours. Fever was considered alleviated when maintained at < 38.0°C (age 20 to < 65 years) or < 37.8°C (age ≥ 65 years) ≥ 21.5 hours.
analysis.p_value_desc: A step-down approach was applied to the primary analysis, with the higher dose of favipiravir first tested against placebo.

group.title: 1: Low Dose Favipiravir

event.description: Patient experienced vulval abscess (CTCAE grade 3) on Day 9 of study. Treated with medication, event resolved 5 days later. Met seriousness criteria of hospitalization. Investigator considered event not related to study drug.

Patient experienced hepatic encephalopathy (CTCAE grade 1) on Day 4 of study. Treatment not required, event resolved 2 days later. PMH of cirrohsis. Event met seriousness criteria of prolonged hospitalization. Determined as unrelated to study drug.

Bronchial obstruction (CTCAE grade 1) Day 2 of study (placebo cohort). Withdrawn from study. Treated with medication, event resolved 4 days later. Met serious criteria of hospitalization. Investigator considered event unrelated to study drug.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
